title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of total complaints received by the Identity Theft Data Clearinghouse for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. Victims may experience damaged credit records, unauthorized charges on credit cards, unauthorized withdrawals from bank accounts, and may need to change personal information like phone numbers and social security numbers. The report provides an overview of federal laws to assist identity theft victims in removing inaccurate information from credit records and unauthorized charges from credit accounts. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud related to identification documents, including cases of consumer identity theft. Impostors could face prosecution under this statute for producing false identification documents without lawful authority. The federal law prohibits the production and possession of false identification documents, as well as the transfer or use of another person's identification without lawful authority. Punishments vary depending on the offense, with fines or imprisonment up to 15 years for certain violations. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed in 2004, amended Title 18 of the United States Code to define and establish penalties for aggravated identity theft. Aggravated identity theft occurs when a person knowingly uses another person's identification during certain felonies, resulting in a two-year imprisonment in addition to the original felony punishment. Offenses committed to facilitate drug trafficking, violence, or international terrorism carry higher imprisonment terms. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 increased penalties for identity theft, including a two-year imprisonment for aggravated identity theft in addition to the original felony punishment. The act also authorized appropriations for the investigation and prosecution of identity theft cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act may assist victims in removing negative information resulting from unauthorized charges or accounts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) outlines consumer rights regarding credit reports, permissible uses, and disclosure requirements. It requires accuracy in reported information and allows consumers to sue for violations, such as inaccurate information due to identity theft. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) allows consumers to sue credit reporting agencies for failing to verify information accurately due to identity theft. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to prevent identity theft and create national standards for addressing consumer concerns. Credit card issuers must follow specific procedures when receiving requests for additional cards after a change of address notification. The FCRA includes provisions to prevent identity theft, such as truncating credit card numbers on receipts and allowing fraud alerts for victims. Consumers can request fraud alerts from one agency, which must notify others, and alerts can be extended for up to seven years. Fraud alerts are included in credit files and passed along to users and credit scores. The FCRA allows victims of identity theft to request fraud alerts, block fraudulent information from credit reports, and request information about the crime. Consumer reporting agencies must block fraudulent information upon receiving proof of identity theft and notify the furnisher of the information. Victims can also request transaction records related to the identity theft. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and billing errors in credit transactions. Consumers can request copies of transaction records related to identity theft, providing proof of the theft. The FCBA aims to protect consumers from inaccurate credit billing practices. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) provides consumers with a mechanism to challenge unauthorized transactions and have their accounts recredited in case of errors. It establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities in electronic fund transfer systems, limiting consumer liability. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities in electronic fund transfer systems. It limits a consumer's liability for unauthorized transfers and requires financial institutions to provide documentation of all electronic transfers initiated by the consumer. If an error is reported within 60 days, the institution must investigate and report the results within 10 business days. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) establishes rights, liabilities, and responsibilities in electronic fund transfer systems. If an error is reported within 60 days, the financial institution must investigate and report the results to the consumer within 10 business days. The consumer must provide specific details when reporting an error, and if the institution confirms an error, they must correct it within one day. The institution may temporarily credit the consumer's account for the disputed amount while investigating. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft in April 2007. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan in April 2007 to crack down on criminals trafficking in stolen identities, protect personal information, educate consumers and businesses, and increase safeguards on personal data. The plan focuses on improving data security, assisting victims of identity theft, and deterring identity theft through aggressive prosecution. Recommendations include amending identity theft statutes to prosecute thieves who misappropriate information from corporations and organizations. The identity theft and aggravated identity theft statutes are being amended to prosecute thieves who steal information from corporations and organizations. New crimes will be added to the list of predicate offenses for aggravated identity theft. The cyber-extortion statute will be amended to cover additional types of cyber-extortion. The Real ID Rule, in accordance with the REAL ID Act of 2005, establishes standards for issuing identification documents. The Real ID Rule sets standards for issuing identification documents, including security features, proof of identity, and verification of source documents. States can receive extensions until December 31, 2009, and those meeting security benchmarks can get a second extension until May 10, 2011. States must replace all licenses with REAL ID-compliant cards by December 1, 2014, for younger individuals and by December 1, 2017, for older individuals. The rule became effective on March 31, 2008.
